title: 111_hr3677
content: The Act titled "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" provides relief payments to recipients of Social Security and Railroad Retirement benefits. The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to disburse a $280 payment to individuals eligible for specific benefit payments in December 2009, January 2010, or February 2010. The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" authorizes the Secretary of the Treasury to disburse specific benefit payments to eligible individuals in December 2009, January 2010, or February 2010 under various sections of the Act (42 U.S.C. 402). The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" authorizes benefit payments under specific sections of the Act, including monthly annuity or pension payments under the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" authorizes benefit payments under specific sections of the Act, including provisions for adult disabled children under various sections of the Railroad Retirement Act of 1974. Payment under section 7(b)(2) is limited to individuals residing in specific locations and individuals are only eligible for one payment regardless of other benefits. The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" allows for benefit payments under certain sections of the Act, with limitations on multiple payments and eligibility criteria based on specific circumstances such as entitlement to certain benefits or date of death. The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" allows for benefit payments under specific sections, with the Secretary of the Treasury required to start payments within 120 days of enactment and no payments disbursed after December 31, 2012. The "Save Our Seniors' Social Security Act of 2009" mandates benefit payments to eligible individuals certified by the Commissioner of Social Security and the Railroad Retirement Board. Payments under this section are not considered income for federal programs. The Retirement Act of 1974 applies to payments made under subsection (a) as benefit payments or cash benefits. Payments under this section are subject to offset for collecting delinquent debts. Payment to representative payees and fiduciaries is also addressed. The Retirement Act of 1974 applies to payments made under subsection (a) as benefit payments or cash benefits. When a payment is made to a representative payee or fiduciary, it must be used for the benefit of the entitled individual. Applicability of payment on the basis of title II or railroad retirement benefits is also addressed. Section 13 of the Railroad Retirement Act applies to payments based on entitlement to specified benefits. An appropriation of $131,000,000 is allocated for administrative costs for fiscal years 2010 through 2012 to carry out this section. Additional funds are appropriated for payments to individuals certified by the Commissioner of Social Security. The Railroad Retirement Act allocates $131,000,000 for administrative costs for fiscal years 2010 through 2012, with a limitation that no funds can be used beyond fiscal year 2012. Effective immediately, a portion of unspent funds from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 will be rescinded to offset increased spending as outlined in section 2. This rescission will be applied proportionately to each discretionary account and within each account to programs, projects, and activities. Within 30 days of this Act, the OMB Director must report to Congress on the reductions made to accounts, programs, projects, and activities.
